refnamediv.refpurpose: an extended version of &pdfTeX; using &Lua; as an embedded scripting language

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Run the &LuaTeX; typesetter on file, usually creating file.pdf. Any remaining commands are processed as &LuaTeX; input, after file is read.
Alternatively, if the first non-option argument begins with a &, the next word is taken as the format to read, overriding all else. Any remaining arguments are processed as above.
If no arguments or options are specified, prompt for input.

&LuaTeX; is an extended version of &pdfTeX; with Unicode and OpenType font support, embeded &Lua; scripting language, the &eTeX; and Ω extensions, as well as integrated &MetaPost; engine, that can create &PDF; files as well as &DVI; files. For more information about &LuaTeX;, see http://www.luatex.org, you can read the &LuaTeX; manual using the &MiKTeXHelpUtility; (&mthelp; luatex).
All &LuaTeX; text input and output is considered to be Unicode text.
In &DVI; mode, &LuaTeX; can be used as a complete replacement for the &TeX; engine.

In &PDF; mode, &LuaTeX; can natively handle the &PDF;, &JPG;, &JBIG2;, and &PNG; graphics formats. &LuaTeX; cannot include &PostScript; or Encapsulated &PostScript; (&EPS;) graphics files; first convert them to &PDF; using miktex-epstopdf1.

refsect1.title: Options
refsect1.para: When the &LuaTeX; executable starts, it looks for the --lua commandline option. If there is no --lua option, the commandline is interpreted in a similar fashion as in traditional &pdfTeX;. But if the option is present, &LuaTeX; will enter an alternative mode of commandline parsing in comparison to the standard &MiKTeX; programs. The presence of --lua makes most of other options unreliable, because the &Lua; initialization file can disable path searching and/or hook functions into various callbacks.

listitem.para:
Load and execute a
--lua=file
&Lua; initialization script.

refsect1.para: The following two options alter the executable behaviour:

listitem.para:
Start &LuaTeX; as a &Lua; interpreter.
--luaonly
In this mode, it will set &Lua;’s arg[0] to the found script name, pushing preceding options in negative values and the rest of the commandline in the positive values, just like the &Lua; interpreter. &LuaTeX; will exit immediately after executing the specified &Lua; script.

Start &LuaTeX; as a &Lua; byte compiler.
--luaconly
In this mode, &LuaTeX; is exactly like luac from the standalone &Lua; distribution, except that it does not have the −l switch, and that it accepts (but ignores) the −−luaconly switch.

Switch on draft mode.
--draftmode
luaTeX; doesn't write a &PDF; and doesn't read any included images, thus speeding up execution.
Enable fmt generation, where fmt must be either tex or tfm.
Disable fmt generation, where fmt must be either tex or tfm.

Use string for &DVI; file comment
--output-comment=string
instead of date.

Use format for job output
--output-format=format
(one of: dvi, pdf).
